History is even less comfortable when a caliph decides to act as executioner – it is possible that these acts are so beyond the pale that they are left by and large unrecorded. We know of three possible cases: al-Ma’mun’s execution of the Abbasid contender Ibn ‘A’ishah, al-Wathiq’s botched attempt at beheading Nasr ibn Ahmad, and Abd al-Rahman III’s ritual sacrifice of his son

title: Any legitimacy that may have accrued to ruling elites through the spectacle of violence was transient and ephemeral, fixed as it was to the moment of death.
